hook.text: A store sells 10% more diapers one week. The warehouse orders 20% more. The factory produces 40% more. Chaos.

buildup.text: The bullwhip effect means small demand changes at the retail level amplify into huge swings upstream.

discovery.text: Each link in the chain overreacts. Safety stock, batch ordering, and forecasting errors all amplify the distortion.

twist.text: The result: factories overproduce, then suddenly face cancellations. Boom-bust cycles that nobody intended.

climax.text: Walmart reduced the bullwhip by sharing real-time point-of-sale data directly with suppliers.

punchline.text: The further from the customer, the louder the noise.

quiz.question: What is the bullwhip effect?
options: Small demand changes at retail amplify into large swings upstream
A whip-like motion used in packaging
A sudden increase in consumer spending
